content:
That's a great file structure! It separates the functionality of the app into logical components and follows the standard Python package conventions.

Here is an updated file structure that includes the api endpoints for the React Native mobile app:
```markdown
├── app/
│   ├── authentication/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── auth.py
│   │   └── azuread.py
│   ├── case_management/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── case.py
│   │   └── shared_case.py
│   ├── image_review/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── image.py
│   │   └── prediction.py
│   ├── logging/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── logger.py
│   │   └── logging.yaml
│   ├── utils/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── datastore.py
│   │   └── notifications.py
│   ├── main.py
│   ├── api/
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── auth.py
│   │   ├── case.py
│   │   ├── shared_case.py
│   │   ├── image.py
│   │   └── prediction.py
├── requirements.txt
└── README.md
```
The `api` directory contains modules with api endpoints for the mobile app. The `__init__.py` file in this directory is empty, but it is needed to make the `api` directory a package.

You can import the api endpoints in `main.py` and add them to the `app` object like this:
```python
from app.api import auth, case, shared_case, image, prediction

app.register_blueprint(auth.auth_bp)
app.register_blueprint(case.case_bp)
app.register_blueprint(shared_case.shared_case_bp)
app.register_blueprint(image.image_bp)
app.register_blueprint(prediction.prediction_bp)
```
Then the endpoints will be available at the following urls:

* `/api/auth`
* `/api/case`
* `/api/shared_case`
* `/api/image`
* `/api/prediction`
